elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A novel cobalt(II) complex [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-oxybis benzoic acid, phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) has been synthesized by hydrothermal method and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, UV–vis, thermal stability and Surface Photovoltage Spectroscopy (SPS). Structural analysis indicated that the complex is a 3D structure with the trinuclear building unit of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] bridged by the oba ligands. The SPS of complex indicates that there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm showing photo-electric conversion properties. There are good relationships between SPS and UV–vis spectra.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
A novel cobalt(II) complex [Co3(oba)3(phen)2]n(H2oba=4,4′-oxybis benzoic acid, phen=1,10-phenanthroline) has been synthesized by hydrothermal method and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, UV–vis, thermal stability and Surface Photovoltage Spectroscopy (SPS). Structural analysis indicated that the complex is a 3D structure with the trinuclear building unit of [Co3(oba)3(phen)2] bridged by the oba ligands. The SPS of complex indicates that there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600nm showing photo-electric conversion properties. There are good relationships between SPS and UV–vis spectra.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">The SPS results of the complex indicated that it possessed clear photovoltaic response bands in UV–vis area (300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). This means that the complex has certain photo-electric conversion properties. And there are good corresponding relationships between SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0035" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
The SPS results of the complex indicated that it possessed clear photovoltaic response bands in UV–vis area (300–600nm). This means that the complex has certain photo-electric conversion properties. And there are good corresponding relationships between SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra.

<ce:figure id="f0005">

</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The novel 3D framework with the trinuclear building unit</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The complex was stable before the temperature reached 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology was used.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The SPS results indicated that it possessed clear photoelectricity conversion.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights



•
The novel 3D framework with the trinuclear building unit


•
The complex was stable before the temperature reached 400°C.


•
Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology was used.


•
The SPS results indicated that it possessed clear photoelectricity conversion.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The novel 3D framework with the trinuclear building unit</ce:para><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The complex was stable before the temperature reached 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology was used.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The SPS results indicated that it possessed clear photoelectricity conversion.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Coordination polymers with practical function and application value  have attracted a huge amount of worldwide activity on the research. The aims of the research of this field are the discovery and synthesis of new complexes, for example, transition metal coordination complexes have applied in the field of light, electricity, magnetism, new materials, catalyst, bionics, biology etc. . In fact, the appearances of many functions of the complexes related not only to their structural types, but also to the changes of their electron behaviors. For example, the different arrangements and couplings of electrons may cause the change of magnetism. The electron transitions and the separation or transfer of photo-generated charges under light-induced may result in the luminescence and photo-electronic conversion properties. Therefore, it is important to make the rule of electron behaviors clearly for the research on the transition metal coordination complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The novel 3D framework with the trinuclear building unit
The complex was stable before the temperature reached 400°C.
Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology was used.
The SPS results indicated that it possessed clear photoelectricity conversion.
Coordination polymers with practical function and application value  have attracted a huge amount of worldwide activity on the research. The aims of the research of this field are the discovery and synthesis of new complexes, for example, transition metal coordination complexes have applied in the field of light, electricity, magnetism, new materials, catalyst, bionics, biology etc. . In fact, the appearances of many functions of the complexes related not only to their structural types, but also to the changes of their electron behaviors. For example, the different arrangements and couplings of electrons may cause the change of magnetism. The electron transitions and the separation or transfer of photo-generated charges under light-induced may result in the luminescence and photo-electronic conversion properties. Therefore, it is important to make the rule of electron behaviors clearly for the research on the transition metal coordination complexes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology, as a very sensitive characterization tool, has been used to detect the charge transitions of the functional semiconductor . Here we report the synthesis , crystal structure , thermal stability and surface photo-electric property of a novel three-dimensional Co(II) complex {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>. It is worthy to note that we used SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra to study the surface electron behaviors under light-induced, and there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm showing photo-electric conversion properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology, as a very sensitive characterization tool, has been used to detect the charge transitions of the functional semiconductor . Here we report the synthesis , crystal structure , thermal stability and surface photo-electric property of a novel three-dimensional Co(II) complex {[Co3(oba)3(phen)2]n. It is worthy to note that we used SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra to study the surface electron behaviors under light-induced, and there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600nm showing photo-electric conversion properties.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The complex is a 3D structure with the three nuclear building unit of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] bridged by the oba ligands, and the asymmetric unit of complex can be seen from 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">There are three Co(II) ions which belong to two kinds of independent crystallograph, two phen and three oba group in each building unit. In the crystal structure, the Co1 is six-coordinated with N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> donor, two N atoms are from the same phen group, two O atoms are from the same oba groups, and the other two O atoms are from the different oba groups. The Co2 is six-coordinated with an O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> donor, in which the six O atoms are from six different oba ligands. As bridging ligand, oba groups also have two coordinated modes: i. both of two carboxyl groups adopt bidentate mode bridging Co1 and Co2 (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor> (a)); ii. one carboxyl group adopts bidentate mode bridging Co1 and Co2, when in the other carboxyl group, one O atom adopts monodentate mode bridging Co1 and the other O atom adopts bidentate mode coordinated to Co1 and Co2 at the same time ( (b)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The complex is a 3D structure with the three nuclear building unit of [Co3(oba)3(phen)2] bridged by the oba ligands, and the asymmetric unit of complex can be seen from 
.
There are three Co(II) ions which belong to two kinds of independent crystallograph, two phen and three oba group in each building unit. In the crystal structure, the Co1 is six-coordinated with N2O4 donor, two N atoms are from the same phen group, two O atoms are from the same oba groups, and the other two O atoms are from the different oba groups. The Co2 is six-coordinated with an O6 donor, in which the six O atoms are from six different oba ligands. As bridging ligand, oba groups also have two coordinated modes: i. both of two carboxyl groups adopt bidentate mode bridging Co1 and Co2 (
 (a)); ii. one carboxyl group adopts bidentate mode bridging Co1 and Co2, when in the other carboxyl group, one O atom adopts monodentate mode bridging Co1 and the other O atom adopts bidentate mode coordinated to Co1 and Co2 at the same time ( (b)).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The oba groups with the second coordinated modes link the adjacent trinuclear building unit to form a 1D infinite chain along the c axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The 3D network structure was formed which linked by the other oba groups (Supplementary materials, Fig. S1). These trinuclear clusters Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> behave as second building units are interconnected through the oba ligands to generate an extended 3D framework. The 3D framework of the complex with permanent porosity. Void volume was estimated to be 22.3% by PLATON software .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The oba groups with the second coordinated modes link the adjacent trinuclear building unit to form a 1D infinite chain along the c axis (
). The 3D network structure was formed which linked by the other oba groups (Supplementary materials, Fig. S1). These trinuclear clusters Co3(COO)6 behave as second building units are interconnected through the oba ligands to generate an extended 3D framework. The 3D framework of the complex with permanent porosity. Void volume was estimated to be 22.3% by PLATON software .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Each trinuclear cluster Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> of the complex is surrounded by six organic ligands, which are essential of the connectivity of the network. As such, each oba ligand is connected to two trinuclear clusters and result in a 2-connected node. Each trinuclear cluster as 6-connected node is further linked by six trinuclear clusters via six oba ligands. As a consequence, the resulting 3D framework can be simplified as 6-connected net with a topology symbol of {4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>} (TD10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1561) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>), which represents pcu topology analyzed by the Topos <ce:italic>4.0</ce:italic> program .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Each trinuclear cluster Co3(COO)6 of the complex is surrounded by six organic ligands, which are essential of the connectivity of the network. As such, each oba ligand is connected to two trinuclear clusters and result in a 2-connected node. Each trinuclear cluster as 6-connected node is further linked by six trinuclear clusters via six oba ligands. As a consequence, the resulting 3D framework can be simplified as 6-connected net with a topology symbol of {412·63} (TD10=1561) (
), which represents pcu topology analyzed by the Topos 4.0 program .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Thermal stability of the complex was determined which used TG technique under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min heating rate in the temperature range of 30–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. As can be seen from 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, the complex was essentially stable before the temperature reached 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the first mass loss is in the range of 400 to 460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the rate of weight loss is 39.11%, which can be considered as six CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules and most of the phen molecules; the second procedure is in the range of 460 to 710<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the rate of weight loss is 44.19% which can be considered as the lost of all phen molecules and the oba group skeleton.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal stability of the complex was determined which used TG technique under N2 atmosphere with 25°C/min heating rate in the temperature range of 30–800°C. As can be seen from 
, the complex was essentially stable before the temperature reached 400°C, the first mass loss is in the range of 400 to 460°C, the rate of weight loss is 39.11%, which can be considered as six CO2 molecules and most of the phen molecules; the second procedure is in the range of 460 to 710°C, the rate of weight loss is 44.19% which can be considered as the lost of all phen molecules and the oba group skeleton.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In the SPS of complex (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>), there is a wide overlapping photovoltaic response band in the range of 300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and four photovoltage response bands treated by Origin 7.0 were obtained: λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>342<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 377<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 568<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The higher intensity response bands at λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>342<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>377<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be attributed to charge transition between ligand and metal, O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co (LMCT) and N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co (LMCT). The response bands at λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 568<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be assigned to d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d* transition of Co(II) ion (<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>A<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>←<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>←<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The higher intensity response bands at λmax
=342nm and λmax
=377nm can be attributed to charge transition between ligand and metal, O→Co (LMCT) and N→Co (LMCT). The response bands at λmax
=429nm and 568nm can be assigned to d→d* transition of Co(II) ion (4A2g
←
4T1g and 4T1g
←
4T1g).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">It is obvious that the UV–vis spectra of complex (Supplementary materials Fig. S2) are corresponding with the SPS. The difference is that the π<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π<ce:sup loc="post">⁎</ce:sup> transition (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≈<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) from the ligand and another d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d* transition (λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) from Co(II) (<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">2g</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>←<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>T<ce:inf loc="post">1g</ce:inf>) in UV–vis do not appear in the SPS because of the limiting region of our SPS (300–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
It is obvious that the UV–vis spectra of complex (Supplementary materials Fig. S2) are corresponding with the SPS. The difference is that the π→π⁎ transition (λ≈260nm) from the ligand and another d→d* transition (λmax
=1000nm) from Co(II) (4T2g
←
4T1g) in UV–vis do not appear in the SPS because of the limiting region of our SPS (300–800nm).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, one novel cobalt(II) complex was synthesized and the structure was determined by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. The surface electron behavior and photo-electric property were discussed by SPS. The SPS results of the complex indicated that it possessed clear photovoltaic response bands in UV–vis area (300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which is photoelectricity conversion. This means that the complex has a certain photo-electric conversion properties. And there are good corresponding relationships between SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, one novel cobalt(II) complex was synthesized and the structure was determined by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. The surface electron behavior and photo-electric property were discussed by SPS. The SPS results of the complex indicated that it possessed clear photovoltaic response bands in UV–vis area (300–600nm), which is photoelectricity conversion. This means that the complex has a certain photo-electric conversion properties. And there are good corresponding relationships between SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra.

Supplementary material
CCDC 908088 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for the complex. The data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or email: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">All reagents were of analytical grade and were used as obtained from commercial sources without further purification. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba (0.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL deionized water and the pH value was adjusted to 8 with 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M NaOH. Under constant stirrer, CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(0.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml aqueous solution was added in the mixture, then light pink turbid solution was obtained, and then phen(0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml ethanol solution was added in the mixture. The mixture was placed in Teflon–lined stainless reactor and heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 4 d. The resulting solution was cooled to room temperature. Pink crystal of complex was obtained. (the yield is ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>50%). for C<ce:inf loc="post">66</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>: anal. calcd, %: C, 60.69; H, 3.07; N, 4.29; O, 18.39. Found, %: C, 60.57; H, 3.32; N, 4.21; O, 18.45. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3433(ν<ce:inf loc="post">OH</ce:inf>); 3063(ν<ce:inf loc="post">NH</ce:inf>); 2920(ν<ce:inf loc="post">Ar-H</ce:inf>); 1607(ν<ce:inf loc="post">as-coo</ce:inf>); 1244(ν<ce:inf loc="post">s-coo</ce:inf>); 1566, 1515, 1400(ν<ce:inf loc="post">C C</ce:inf>).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: All reagents were of analytical grade and were used as obtained from commercial sources without further purification. H2oba (0.13g, 0.5mmol) was dissolved in 10mL deionized water and the pH value was adjusted to 8 with 1M NaOH. Under constant stirrer, CoCl2·6H2O(0.12g, 0.5mmol) in 10ml aqueous solution was added in the mixture, then light pink turbid solution was obtained, and then phen(0.2g, 1mmol) in 5ml ethanol solution was added in the mixture. The mixture was placed in Teflon–lined stainless reactor and heated at 160°C for 4 d. The resulting solution was cooled to room temperature. Pink crystal of complex was obtained. (the yield is ~50%). for C66H40Co3N4O15: anal. calcd, %: C, 60.69; H, 3.07; N, 4.29; O, 18.39. Found, %: C, 60.57; H, 3.32; N, 4.21; O, 18.45. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3433(νOH); 3063(νNH); 2920(νAr-H); 1607(νas-coo); 1244(νs-coo); 1566, 1515, 1400(νC C).

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">X-ray diffraction data of the coordination polymer was collected with the Bruker Smart APEX II X-diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 293(2) K and IP technique Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by fullmatrix least-squares method on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. There are void in the crystal structure. Further details of X-ray structural analysis are given in supplementary materials Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in supplementary materials Table S2.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction data of the coordination polymer was collected with the Bruker Smart APEX II X-diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at 293(2) K and IP technique Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by fullmatrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. There are void in the crystal structure. Further details of X-ray structural analysis are given in supplementary materials Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in supplementary materials Table S2.

metadata.title: Synthesis, structure, thermal stability and surface photo-electric property of a novel three-dimensional Co(II) complex
